name: Yarrow
description: Used to stop bleeding and heal minor cuts.
instructions: Apply crushed fresh leaves directly to the wound. Can also be brewed into a tea for fevers.

name: Elderberry
description: Helps reduce the duration of cold and flu.
instructions: Simmer berries to make a syrup. Take 1 tablespoon daily during cold season.

name: Chamomile
description: Eases anxiety and helps with sleep.
instructions: Steep dried flowers in hot water for 10 minutes to make a calming tea.

name: Echinacea
description: Boosts the immune system and fights infections.
instructions: Take as a tincture or tea at the first sign of illness, up to 3 times per day.

name: Peppermint
description: Relieves indigestion and soothes the stomach.
instructions: Use fresh or dried leaves to make a tea. Sip after meals.

name: Lavender
description: Promotes relaxation and eases headaches.
instructions: Inhale essential oil or add flowers to a sachet placed near the pillow.

name: Comfrey
description: Traditionally used to heal bruises, sprains, and broken bones.
instructions: Use as a poultice on unbroken skin. Do not ingest.

name: Valerian
description: Promotes restful sleep and reduces insomnia.
instructions: Take as a tincture or capsule 30 minutes before bedtime.

name: Slippery Elm
description: Soothes sore throats and irritated stomach linings.
instructions: Mix powdered bark with warm water into a gruel or tea.

name: Goldenseal
description: Used as a natural antibiotic and to treat infections.
instructions: Use tincture or tea. Limit use to short periods.

name: St. John’s Wort
description: Helps relieve mild to moderate depression.
instructions: Take as tea or capsule. Avoid sun exposure and consult doctor if on medications.

name: Nettle
description: Used to treat joint pain and seasonal allergies.
instructions: Steep dried leaves for tea, or cook fresh leaves like spinach.

name: Dandelion
description: Supports liver function and digestion.
instructions: Use root or leaves in tea or eat fresh greens in salad.

name: Licorice Root
description: Soothes sore throats and supports lung function.
instructions: Simmer dried root to make tea. Do not use long-term or with high blood pressure.

name: Calendula
description: Heals wounds, burns, and skin irritations.
instructions: Infuse in oil for salves, or apply as cooled tea compress.

name: Plantain
description: Draws out toxins and speeds up healing of insect bites and cuts.
instructions: Crush fresh leaves and apply as poultice or brew for a rinse.

name: Hawthorn
description: Supports heart health and circulation.
instructions: Use berries, leaves, and flowers in tincture or tea form daily.

name: Willow Bark
description: Contains salicin, a natural pain reliever like aspirin.
instructions: Simmer bark in water to make tea. Use short term for pain relief.

name: Milk Thistle
description: Protects and regenerates liver cells.
instructions: Take standardized extract in capsule form or as tea.

name: Mullein
description: Eases coughs and inflammation of the respiratory tract.
instructions: Steep dried leaves in hot water for tea. Strain well before drinking.

name: Ashwagandha
description: Used to reduce stress, improve energy and vitality.
instructions: Take as a powdered root mixed in warm milk or as capsules/tincture.
tradition: Ayurveda – used for rejuvenation and nervous system support.
grow_info: Grows in dry, sunny climates. Can be cultivated in warm regions.
foraging_notes: Not found wild in North America; grow from seed.

name: Tulsi (Holy Basil)
description: Supports immunity and lung health, relieves stress.
instructions: Drink as tea daily or take as a tincture.
tradition: Ayurveda – sacred herb known as the 'Queen of Herbs.'
grow_info: Easy to grow annually in most climates; loves sun.
foraging_notes: Not found wild in North America; grows easily in pots.
